Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Carotid Artery Stenting and Endarterectomy in Asymptomatic Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 2544 patients with ≥70% asymptomatic carotid stenosis were randomised to CAS or CEA, alongside standard medical therapy.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to CAS or CEA, alongside standard medical therapy

Objective.evidence: This study compares outcomes of CAS versus CEA in asymptomatic, non-octogenarian patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary composite endpoint was any stroke, myocardial infarction, or death during the periprocedural period or ipsilateral stroke within 4 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 2544 patients with ≥70% asymptomatic carotid stenosis were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: Participants were recruited from two trials, with 1091 (548 CAS, 543 CEA) and 1453 (1089 CAS, 364 CEA) patients, respectively.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary endpoint showed no significant difference between CAS and CEA (5.3% vs. 5.1%, HR = 1.02; 95% CI 0.7–1.5; P=.91).

Harms.evidence: Periprocedural stroke rates were 2.7% for CAS and 1.5% for CEA (P=.07). Myocardial infarction rates were 0.6% for CAS and 1.7% for CEA (P=.01). Death rates were 0.1% for CAS and 0.2% for CEA (P=.62).
